facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2262 of 1966 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2262 of 1966.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated April 22, 1966 of Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 439 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 22, 1966 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 439 of 1965.

facts.text: Appellants are a partnership firm carrying on business of manufacturing and selling bidis and purchase, stock, transport and consume considerable quantity of tendu leaves.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are a partnership firm carrying on the business of manufacturing and selling bidis and purchase, stock, transport and companysume for that purpose companysiderable quantity of tendu leaves.

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh Tendu Patta Vyapar Viniyaman Adhiniyam, 29 of 1964 passed by State Legislature in 1964.

anchor.surface_text: In 1964, the State Legislature passed the Madhya Pradesh Tendu Patta  Vyapar Viniyaman  Adhiniyam, 29 of 1964  hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: Act received President's assent on November 23, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The Act received the Presidents assent on November 23, 1964 and was brought into force on November 28, 1964.

facts.text: Act brought into force on November 28, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The Act received the Presidents assent on November 23, 1964 and was brought into force on November 28, 1964.

facts.text: Act creates State monopoly in trade of tendu leaves.

anchor.surface_text: The Act inter alia created a State monopoly in the trade of tendu leaves and under S. 5 1  thereof prohibited anyone, excepting those mentioned therein, either to purchase or transport tendu leaves.

facts.text: Section 5(1) prohibits purchase or transport of tendu leaves except by specified persons.

anchor.surface_text: under S. 5 1  thereof prohibited anyone, excepting those mentioned therein, either to purchase or transport tendu leaves.

facts.text: Section 5(2) permits grower to transport tendu leaves within unit and purchaser with permit to transport outside unit.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-s. 2 of s. 5, however, permitted a grower to transport them within the unit where they grow and a purchaser who has purchased them from the State Government, its authorised officers and agents for manufacturing bidis or for exporting outside the State to transport them outside such unit under a permit and in -accordance with the terms and companyditions thereof.

facts.text: State Government framed rules: Madhya Pradesh Tendu Patta Vyapar Viniyaman Niyamavali, 1965 under S.19.

anchor.surface_text: By virtue of S. 19 the State Government framed rules called the Madhya Pradesh Tendu Patta  Vyapar Viniyaman  Niyamavali, 1965  referred to hereinafter as the rules .

facts.text: Rule 9 provides for application for transport permit in form M and issuance in form N.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 9 of the said rules provided for an application for a transport permit in form M and the issuance of such permit in form N.

facts.text: Appellants applied for and obtained permits to transport tendu leaves from forest units to godowns outside units.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants accordingly applied for and obtained permits authorising them to transport tendu leaves purchased by them from the various forest units to their godowns situate outside those units.

facts.text: Appellants transport leaves from units to warehouses, then to branches, distribute to sattedars who are independent contractors, who distribute to mazdoors for rolling bidis.

anchor.surface_text: In the companyrse of their business the appellants transport the said leaves first from the said units to their warehouses, from there to their branches and thereafter distribute them and tobacco to their sattedars, who are independent companytractors, and who in their turn distribute the said leaves and tobacco to various mazdoors living in different villages for rolling the bidis.

facts.text: Sattedars enter contracts with appellants under which appellants supply leaves and tobacco, sattedars deliver rolled bidis.

anchor.surface_text: According to the practice of the appellants, the said sattedars enter into companytracts with them under which the appellants supply to them the said leaves -and the tobacco and the sattedars deliver to the appellants bidis rolled by the mazdoors in proportion to the quantity of the leaves and tobacco supplied to them.

facts.text: On June 4, 1965, Divisional Forest Officer issued order forbidding movement of old tendu leaves, requiring permits for new leaves village to village, and for bulk transport from warehouses to branches and sattedars.

anchor.surface_text: On June 4, 1965, the Divisional Forest Officer issued an order which forbade altogether movement of old tendu leaves and as regards new leaves provided that their movement from one village to another had to be companyered by a permit. It also provided that permits would be necessary for bulk transport from warehouses to branches and from there to sattedars, and that such permits would be issued by range assistants and range officers on receipt of applications therefore.

facts.text: Appellants made representation to Divisional Forest Officer about difficulties from June 4 order.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants thereupon made a representation to the Divisional Forest Officer mentioning the several difficulties which would result from the Said order

facts.text: Divisional Forest Officer by order dated June 8, 1965 partially modified June 4 order, permitting branch managers of bidi firms to issue transport permits to sattedars.

anchor.surface_text: and the said officer, by his order dated June 8, 1965, in partial modification of his said order, permitted branch managers of bidi manufacturing firms themselves to issue transport permits to sattedars.

facts.text: On October 12, 1965, Divisional Forest Officer rescinded June 8, 1965 order because branch managers issued permits for bulk transport instead of distribution.

anchor.surface_text: Finding, however, that instead of distributing the said leaves to the sattedars, the branch managers were issuing permits for bulk transport, the said officer on October 12, 1965 rescinded his order of June 8, 1965.

facts.text: Appellants filed writ petition in MP High Court claiming permits only needed from units to warehouses, no further restrictions; sought mandamus against June 4 and Oct 12 orders and to strike down s.5 if broadly construed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants thereafter filed the said writ petition in the High Court claiming that under s. 5 and the said rules they were required to obtain permits only when moving the leaves purchased by them from units where they were grown to their warehouses and that once they were so moved to the warehouses there companyld be numberrestriction in their further movement from the warehouses to their branches and from there to their sattedars and the mazdoors.

facts.text: High Court dismissed writ petition, held permit necessary even outside unit under s.5(2)(b), s.5 valid under Art.19(6), restrictions integral to monopoly.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that on a proper companystruction of S. 5  2   b  a permit was necessary for transport of the leaves by a purchaser number only when he moved them from the units where they were purchased to a place outside but also when he moved them from one place to another outside the said unit, that S. 5  1 , being a provision creating the State monopoly in the trade of tendu leaves, was protected by the latter part of Art. 19  6  of the Constitution, that the restriction imposed by s. 5  1  on transport was valid and that sub-s. 2 being merely a relaxation against the said prohibition was valid.

facts.text: State claimed restrictions justified under s.5 and rules.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government, on the other hand, claimed that the restrictions against transport of the leaves were justified under s. 5 and the rules and were valid.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal under certificate against High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal under certificate is directed against the judgment of the High Court of Madhya Pradesh dismissing the writ petition filed by the appellants in that Court.

facts.text: Appellants manufacture 1-1/2 crores of bidis a day, have network of branches.

anchor.surface_text: According to the appellants, they manufacture as many as 1-1/2 crores of bidis a day. They have established a net-work of branches in several areas of the State.

facts.text: 6 or 7 thousand sattedars in Saugor district alone.

anchor.surface_text: Even according to the Divisional Forest Officer there were as many as 6 or 7 thousand sattedars in Saugor district alone with whom manufacturers of bidis had companytracts as mentioned -above.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds permits required up to sattedars but not for distribution to mazdoors.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, reading s. 5  2  along with rule 9 of the said rules, what they are intended to require is that a manufacturer must have a permit to move the leaves purchased by him from the unit or units where he has purchased them to his warehouse outside and from there to his branches -and also when he transports them to his sattedars. But, numbersuch permit was intended to be necessary when the leaves are distributed for the manufacture of bidis by these sattedars to the mazdoors whom he employs.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal under certificate is directed against the judgment of the High Court of Madhya Pradesh dismissing the writ petition filed by the appellants in that Court.
CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2262 of 1966. Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 22, 1966 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 439 of 1965.

issues.text: whether the restrictions are an integral part of the trade monopoly it seeks to create, and therefore, free from any challenge as to their reasonableness under the latter part of Art. 19(6)

anchor.surface_text: 1  whether the restrictions are an integral part of the trade monopoly it seeks to create, and therefore, free from any challenge as to their reasonableness under the latter part of Art. 19  6  , and  2  as regards its

issues.text: as regards its interpretation and scope

anchor.surface_text: 1  whether the restrictions are an integral part of the trade monopoly it seeks to create, and therefore, free from any challenge as to their reasonableness under the latter part of Art. 19  6  , and  2  as regards its interpretation and scope.

issues.text: the scope of the embargo on movement imposed by s. 5

anchor.surface_text: That leads us to the next question as to the scope of the embargo on movement imposed by s. 5. If read literally, sub- s. 1 places -a total ban on any and every person against transporting the leaves,

issues.text: s. 5(2)(b) should be construed to mean that it prohibits without permit movement of tendu leaves from the units where they are purchased to the warehouses of the purchaser outside such units [...] once they were [...] brought to his warehouse there could no longer be any necessity to restrict their movement [...] to the stage of their consumption in manufacturing the bidis

anchor.surface_text: 1  that s. 5  2   b  should be construed, though it is couched in wide language, to mean that it prohibits without permit movement of tendu leaves from the units where they are purchased to the warehouses of the purchaser outside such units, that that restriction alone was necessary for effectively implementing the States monopoly in tendu leaves,

issues.text: neither s. 5(2)(b) nor the rules authorise restrictions on the movement of these leaves once they were brought under a permit to the warehouse, and therefore, the order dated June 4, 1965 [...] was ultra vires the section and the rules

anchor.surface_text: 2  that neither s. 5  2   b nor the rules authorise restrictions on the movement of these leaves once they were brought under a permit to the warehouse, and therefore, the order dated June 4, 1965, requiring the purchaser to obtain permits for transporting them from his warehouse to his branch and from there to the sattedars and the mazdoors was ultra vires the section and the rules

issues.text: the restrictions as to transport were ancillary to and were for the effective enforcement of the trade monopoly and not an essential or integral part of the scheme of that monopoly, that they were, therefore, not protected by the latter part of Art. 19(6) or Art. 304(b), and have, therefore, to pass the test of reasonableness

anchor.surface_text: 3  that the restrictions as to transport were ancillary to and were for the effective enforcement of the trade monopoly and not an essential or integral part of the scheme of that monopoly, that they were, therefore, not protected by the latter part of Art. 19 6  or Art. 304 b , and have, therefore, to pass the test of reasonableness and

issues.text: if S. 5 were to be literally construed so as to mean that it authorises the restriction on movement after the leaves were warehoused requiring permits [...] until they reached the mazdoors, the entire system of permits would become unworkable and the restrictions would have to be held as unreasonable [...] violative of Art. 19(1)(f) and (g) and Arts. 301 and 304

anchor.surface_text: 4  that, if S. 5 were to be literally construed so as to mean that it authorises the restriction on movement after the leaves were warehoused requiring permits for their transport from stage to stage until they reached the mazdoors, the entire system of permits would become unworkable and the restrictions would have to be held as unreasonable that such a construction rendering S. 5 and the rules unconstitutional on the ground of being violative of Art. 19 1   f  and  g  and Arts. 301 and 304 could not have been intended by the legislature.

issues.text: the language of S. 5 was clear and unambiguous, that it forbade without permit transport at any stage right upto the stage of manufacture of the bidis and that those restrictions were the essential part of the scheme of the State monopoly and therefore were protected by the latter part of Art. 19(6) and further that even if they were not, they were reasonable restrictions and therefore permissible

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the State, on the other hand, maintained that the language of S. 5 was clear and unambiguous, that it forbade without permit transport at any stage right upto the stage of manufacture of the bidis and that those restrictions were the essential part of the scheme of the State monopoly and therefore were protected by the latter part of Art. 19  6  and further that even if they were not, they were reasonable restrictions and therefore permissible.

arguments.court_reasoning: Monopoly in purchase/sale per long title; transport post-sale extraneous, ancillary; follows Akadasi distinguishing core from incidental

arguments.claim: Literal construction of s.5 authorizing stage-by-stage permits until mazdoors unworkable, unreasonable, violative of Art.19(1)(f),(g), 301,304; legislature could not intend

anchor.surface_text: 4 that, if S. 5 were to be literally construed so as to mean that it authorises the restriction on movement after the leaves were warehoused requiring permits for their transport from stage to stage until they reached the mazdoors, the entire system of permits would become unworkable and the restrictions would have to be held as unreasonable that such a construction rendering S. 5 and the rules unconstitutional on the ground of being violative of Art. 19 1 f and g and Arts. 301 and 304 could not have been intended by the legislature.

arguments.qualifiers: if ... were to be literally construed
arguments.court_reasoning: Presume constitutionality; read down using object, long title to limit permits to sattedars stage avoiding unconstitutionality

arguments.claim: S.5 language clear/unambiguous; forbids without permit transport at any stage up to bidis manufacture; restrictions essential part of monopoly scheme protected by latter Art.19(6); alternatively reasonable

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the State, on the other hand, maintained that the language of S. 5 was clear and unambiguous, that it forbade without permit transport at any stage right upto the stage of manufacture of the bidis and that those restrictions were the essential part of the scheme of the State monopoly and therefore were protected by the latter part of Art. 19 6 and further that even if they were not, they were reasonable restrictions and therefore permissible.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ourt declined to treat s. 4 of that Act which companyferred the exclusive right to fix the prices on the State as ail integral and organic part of the

arguments.court_reasoning: Transport not integral to trade (purchase/sale); ancillary per Akadasi; but reasonable up to sattedars

arguments.claim: Permit under s.5(2)(b) necessary not only from unit but any movement outside unit; s.5(1) creates monopoly protected by Art.19(6) latter part; transport restriction valid, s.5(2) mere relaxation; integral to prevent surreptitious sales/mixing

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that on a proper construction of S. 5 2 b a permit was necessary for transport of the leaves by a purchaser not only when he moved them from the units where they were purchased to a place outside but also when he moved them from one place to another outside the said unit, that S. 5 1 , being a provision creating the State monopoly in the trade of tendu leaves, was protected by the latter part of Art. 19 6 of the Constitution,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ourt declined to treat s. 4 of that Act which companyferred the exclusive right to fix the prices on the State as ail integral and organic part of the

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguishes transport as ancillary not core; literal reading too broad, read down; partly reasonable only to sattedars

arguments.claim: Restrictions on transport integral/organic to monopoly to check movement, prevent smuggling/loopholes in illegitimate acquisition/sales

anchor.surface_text: It may be as stated in the States counter-affidavit that the trade monopoly can be effectively implemented only if the movement of the leaves is checked and regulated by confining the right of free movement to the State and its agents and under permits to the manufacturers of bidis and the exporters and that if free movement were allowed there would be loopholes which would suffer illegitimate acquisitions and sales in leaves smuggled through the areas where they grow,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: red from one another engages itself in bidi-rolling labour. It is also companyceivable that in some of the households number only the adults but the m

arguments.court_reasoning: Some check necessary; reasonable up to sattedars balancing object vs inconvenience

arguments.claim: Only essential/basic provisions for creating monopoly protected by Art.19(6) latter part; subsidiary/incidental like transport tested under first part

anchor.surface_text: Laws protected by Art. 19 6 are regarded as valid even though they impinge upon the fundamental right guaranteed under Art. 19 1 That is the effect of the scheme contained in Art. 19 I read with clauses 2 to 6 of the said Article. ... the said expression should be construed to mean the law relating to the monopoly in its absolutely essential features.

arguments.claim: Trade monopoly per long title is purchase/sale; transport post-purchase extraneous, not integral part

anchor.surface_text: The long, title of the Act clearly says that it was passed for regulating trade in tendu leaves in the public interest by creating the State monopoly in that trade, that is to say, in the purchase and sale of tendu leaves by the State alone and not for creating a monopoly in their transport.

arguments.claim: S.5(2) read with rule 9 requires permits from unit to warehouse, branches, sattedars but not sattedars to mazdoors; inherent limitations from object/long title

anchor.surface_text: In our view, reading s. 5 2 along with rule 9 of the said rules, what they are intended to require is that a manufacturer must have a permit to move the leaves purchased by him from the unit or units where he has purchased them to his warehouse outside and from there to his branches and also when he transports them to his sattedars. But, no such permit was intended to be necessary when the leaves are distributed for the manufacture of bidis by these sattedars to the mazdoors whom he employs.

arguments.claim: Permit system up to sattedars reasonable considering Act object, economic conditions, mischief; beyond unreasonable due to inconvenience to thousands sattedars/mazdoors; checks like stock registers sufficient

anchor.surface_text: In our view a permit system which regulates the movement of leaves purchased by a manufacturer of bidis from the unit where they are purchased to his warehouse, then to the branches and to the sattedars cannot upto that stage be regarded as unreasonable in the light of the object of the Act, the economic conditions prevailing in the State and the mischief which it seeks to cure. At the same time to expect the manufacturer to get permits issued to his sattedars for distribution by them to the innumerable mazdoors of comparatively small quantities of these leaves would be not only unreasonable but frustrating.

arguments.claim: Courts presume constitutionality, lean to uphold; construe considering object, mischief; avoid literal if leads to absurdity/unconstitutionality

anchor.surface_text: In cases of such a kind, two rules of construction have to be kept in mind 1 that courts generally lean towards the constitutionality of a legislative measure impugned before them upon the presumption that a legislature would not deliberately flout a constitutional safeguard or right, and 2 that while construing such an enactment the court must examine the object and the purpose of the impugned Act, the mischief it seeks to prevent and ascertain from such factors its true scope and meaning.

holdings.text: The restrictions on transport contained in s. 5 are not an integral or essential part of the State monopoly in trade of tendu leaves but are ancillary or incidental thereto for effective enforcement and must pass the test of reasonableness under the first part of Art. 19(6), Art. 19(5) and Art. 304(b).

anchor.surface_text: That leads us to the next question as to the scope of the embargo on movement imposed by s. 5. If read literally, sub- s. 1 places -a total ban on any and every person against transporting the leaves,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Long title limits monopoly to purchase and sale; transport post-sale extraneous; follows Akadasi Padhan distinguishing essential core from incidental provisions.

holdings.text: Reading s.5(2) with Rule 9, permits are required for transport of tendu leaves by manufacturer from purchase unit to warehouse, then to branches, and to sattedars, but no permit required for distribution by sattedars to mazdoors.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, reading s. 5  2  along with rule 9 of the said rules, what they are intended to require is that a manufacturer must have a permit to move the leaves purchased by him from the unit or units where he has purchased them to his warehouse outside and from there to his branches -and also when he transports them to his sattedars. But, nosuch permit was intended to be necessary when the leaves are distributed for the manufacture of bidis by these sattedars to the mazdoors whom he employs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction with rules/forms; inherent limits from Act object and long title; avoids unconstitutionality by reading down wide language.

holdings.text: Permit system regulating movement up to sattedars is reasonable restriction in light of Act's object, economic conditions, and mischief to be prevented.

anchor.surface_text: In our view a permit system which regulates the movement of leaves purchased by a manufacturer of bidis from the unit where they are purchased to his warehouse, then to the branches and to the sattedars cannot upto that stage be regarded as unreasonable in the light of the object of the Act, the economic conditions prevailing in the State and the mischief which it seeks to cure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Balances public interest in preventing smuggling against business inconvenience; sufficient checks via stock registers etc.; unreasonable beyond sattedars due to scale of sattedars/mazdoors.

holdings.text: S.5 and Rule 9 are constitutionally valid when construed to require permits only up to sattedars stage.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Presumption of constitutionality; purposive construction upholds via inherent limits; literal reading avoided as leads to unworkability and rights violation.

holdings.text: Order dated June 4, 1965 valid except to extent requiring permit for distribution to mazdoors; order dated October 12, 1965 merely cancels concession and not challengeable as unreasonable restriction.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Orders within scope of validly interpreted S.5 and rules; ban on old leaves conceded; rescission not new restriction.

precedents.citation: Akadasi Padhan v. State of Orissa 1 1963 Supp. 2 S.C.R. 691

anchor.surface_text: Akadasi Padhan v. State of Orissa 1 . Dealing with cl. 6 of Art. 19 and its impact on cls. f and g of Art. 19 1 this Court laid down -at page 707 of the report as follows In dealing with the question about the precise denotation of the clause a law relating to, it is necessary to bear in mind that this clause occurs in Art. 19 6 which is, in a sense, an exception to the main provision of Art. 19 1 g . Laws protected by Art. 19 6 are regarded as valid even though they impinge upon the fundamental right guaranteed under Art. 19 1 That is the effect of the scheme contained in Art. 19 I read with clauses 2 to 6 of the said Article. That being so it would be unreasonable to place upon the relevant clause an unduly wide and liberal construction. A law relating to -a State monopoly cannot, in the context, include all the provisions contained in the said law whether they have direct relation with the creation of the monopoly or not. In our opinion, the said expression should be construed to mean the law relating to the monopoly in its absolutely essential features.

precedents.case_name: Akadasi Padhan v. State of Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: The expression 'law relating to a State monopoly' in Art. 19(6) protects only the essential and basic provisions necessary for creating the monopoly; subsidiary, incidental provisions must satisfy the test of reasonableness under the first part of Art. 19(6)
precedents.cited_holding: ss. 3 and 4 of the Orissa Kendu Leaves (Control of Trade) Act: s. 3 (exclusive purchase) integral and protected; s. 4 (price fixing) not integral but reasonable

precedents.citation: Saghir Ahmad v. The State of U.P. 1 1955 1 S.C.R. 707

anchor.surface_text: cf. Saghir Ahmad v. The State of U.P.  1  and Khyerbari Tea Co. Ltd. v. The State of Assam  2  . That leads us to the next question as to the scope of the embargo on movement imposed by s. 5. If read literally, sub- s. 1 places -a total ban on any and every person against transporting the leaves, except those only mentioned in cls. a , b and c therein. Sub-s. 2 also, if read literally, would mean that an exception is made only in the case of a a grower who can move his leaves freely but within the unit where they have grown, and b . a purchaser who has purchased the leaves for manufacturing bidis within the State or for their export outside the State, but under a permit and in accordance with its terms and conditions. Section 5 read thus, therefore, would mean that except for these two categories of persons, noone can apply for a permit to move the leaves from one place to another as if the legislature intended that the leaves must remain where they -are when purchased.

precedents.case_name: Saghir Ahmad v. State of U.P.
precedents.cited_proposition: The burden of showing that a restrictive law falls under the protective provisions of Art. 19(5) or (6) is on the party seeking protection, not on the citizen challenging it

precedents.citation: Khyerbari Tea Co. Ltd. v. The State of Assam 2 1964 5 S.C.R.975, 1003

anchor.surface_text: and Khyerbari Tea Co. Ltd. v. The State of Assam  2  . That leads us to the next question as to the scope of the embargo on movement imposed by s. 5. If read literally, sub- s. 1 places -a total ban on any and every person against transporting the leaves, except those only mentioned in cls. a , b and c therein. Sub-s. 2 also, if read literally, would mean that an exception is made only in the case of a a grower who can move his leaves freely but within the unit where they have grown, and b . a purchaser who has purchased the leaves for manufacturing bidis within the State or for their export outside the State, but under a permit and in accordance with its terms and conditions. Section 5 read thus, therefore, would mean that except for these two categories of persons, noone can apply for a permit to move the leaves from one place to another as if the legislature intended that the leaves must remain where they -are when purchased. Does it mean that a person who purchases these leaves for purposes other than manufacture of bidis or export cannot move them even from the unit where he has purchased to his place of residence or business ? That would appear to be so because the provisions for a permit apply only to the manufacturer of bidis and the exporter and to noother purchaser.

precedents.case_name: Khyerbari Tea Co. Ltd. v. State of Assam
precedents.cited_proposition: The burden of showing that a restrictive law falls under the protective provisions of Art. 19(5) or (6) is on the party seeking protection, not on the citizen challenging it

anchor.surface_text: So construed, the restrictions against free transport cannot be held to be unreasonable and the validity of s. 5 and rule 9 as also the order of June 4, 1965, except to the extent of its requiring a permit for distribution to the mazdoors, cannot be successfully challenged.
